ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned many techniques of writing Japanese that I did not have before. I also learned a lot about Japanese writers and culture through them, whether it was about Kawabata Yasunari, Oe Kenzaburo, etc.
Improved my Japanese speaking, reading, and writing. Learned more kanji, and also interacted with some pretty cool short texts (from authors like Murakami and Kawabata)
I primarily furthered my reading and kanji.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think just the virtual format made it hard to communicate sometimes. Other than that, this class was so great. I learned so much about Japanese and Stever-sensei was amazing.

The course is taught by one of my favorite professors that I've had at Yale, and I enjoyed the small class size with dedicated classmates. 
The main weakness is the workload. Homework consistently took longer than any other class, and I spent the majority of my study time doing Japanese homework per week. Long readings with new vocabulary and grammar, content worksheets and grammar practice all took time, but the additional quiz every class meant there was just too much review that needed to be done, especially given that class was sometimes only two days apart, in the middle of the week when other homework would be due. 
This workload would probably be easier for our class's native or heritage speakers, but I'm finding myself having to take time away from Japanese because I cannot continue having to rush other classwork to get everything done.
I think the final project is a bit odd given this all virtual setting. Besides that, all course materials are carefully thought of and very well designed to keep us informed and engaged.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think sometimes it was hard to coordinate with other students in the class just because of zoom and the fact that the class size was so small. But, it still was better than most of my other classes I had had.
I really enjoyed the class atmosphere, our discussions were interesting despite being virtual. Our professor managed the zoom calls very well.
I think the final project is a bit hard since everything is virtual and we have to conduct so many interviews with people in various time zones.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! if they are serious about learning Japanese, this class is very beneficial.
Yes, if you took 150 and enjoyed it, 151 is very similar and builds on the skills and materials from the previous semester/year.

I would recommend it to someone who has a very strong background in Japanese reading and grammar or to someone who has a lighter course workload.   It's a good way to improve your language skills, but takes a very substantial amount of time.
Definitely. Mari-sensei is a very good instructor to keep everyone engaged and participated.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
